## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I'm a bit confused about Verus and its relationship with fractional reserve currencies. Can you help clarify something for me? Why can't Verus be converted to native fractional reserve currencies through manual transactions?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, that's a misconception! Verus can be converted to native fractional reserve currencies through simple transactions and PBaaS reserve protocols in a fully automatic way, at any time and for virtually any volume. There is no need for manual transactions. Verus is designed to be flexible and adaptable, and this is just one example of that.

**User:**
Hmm, I see. I thought I read somewhere that Verus fractional reserve currencies aren't native to Verus PBaaS chains. Is that true?

**AI Assistant:**
No, that's not accurate. Verus fractional reserve currencies are, in fact, the native currencies of Verus PBaaS chains that choose to share liquidity across the Verus ecosystem. They're an integral part of the Verus system and are designed to work seamlessly with PBaaS chains.

**User:**
Okay, got it. One more question: Will Verus PBaaS chains not have control over Verus Coin reserves on the Verus blockchain?

**AI Assistant:**
Verus PBaaS chains that are launched as Verus fractional reserves will indeed control a certain amount of Verus Coin on the Verus blockchain, which will serve as the reserves for those chains. So, yes, they will have control over those reserves.
Why can't Verus be converted to native fractional reserve currencies through manual transactions?

Actually, Verus can be converted to native fractional reserve currencies through simple transactions and PBaaS reserve protocols in a fully automatic way, at any time and for virtually any volume. There is no need for manual transactions.

Title: Verus Public Blockchains as a Service: Fractional Reserve Currencies
Article URL: https://medium.com/veruscoin/verus-public-blockchains-as-a-service-fractional-reserve-currencies-274c8b3b3a94
Content:Verus Public Blockchains as a Service: Fractional Reserve Currencies
Photo by istolethetv under the CC by 2.0 license
Just as Elon Musk said it would probably be easier to land a craft on Mars than convince NASA that he could, we believe focusing resources on completing the best possible implementation of Public Blockchains as a Service (PBaaS) rather than telling people all about how great it will be is how to get this technology to the people of the world sooner rather than later, so they can benefit from and experience it themselves.
That said, my heads down focus and that of other Verus developers in the past few weeks may have left some community members otherwise used to seeing me around Discord on a daily basis wondering what exactly is going on behind their screens. I’ve put together this update on Verus PBaaS reserves, and the state of community development at the present to help briefly explain some things.
At any time and for virtually any volume, Verus will be convertible in a fully automatic way between Verus and native fractional reserve currencies through simple transactions and PBaaS reserve protocols.
Verus fractional reserve currencies will be the native currencies of Verus PBaaS chains that choose to share liquidity across the Verus ecosystem. All PBaaS blockchains that are launched as Verus fractional reserves will control a certain amount of Verus Coin on the Verus blockchain that will serve as the reserves for those chains. The reserves may represent 100%, 50%, or even 10% of the total market cap of a PBaaS blockchain.
Explaining the details of how these fractional reserve currencies work is not the purpose of this update. Although PBaaS reser
